title: What are uneducated but highly intelligent people like? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have never known a highly intelligent person who was “uneducated.” “Un-documented” maybe, in that highly intelligent people are often turned off (especially in the United States) by the ploddingly slow pace of “formal education” in American classrooms. This problem has been known for many many decades, but remains unaddressed to this day. As a result, many highly SELF EDUCATED people have no “attendance earned” college degrees, though some self educated individuals may have one or more HONORARY Degrees given to them by colleges or universities that want to tie that self educated person’s fame and contributions to the honorary degree awarding university. I’m not one of those recipients, but… Chances are that I am one of the “uneducated highly intelligent people” you’re asking about. I’m “self taught” through and through. Taught myself to read when I was three. I was reading at a 9th grade level and doing “arithmetic” at a 5th grade level by my first day of school. Not knowing how else to grade me, my first grade teacher assigned me a group of six classmates and told me to teach them how to read. I did that. She also told my mother not to allow me to do any more arithmetic because doing so would impair the development of my “female brain.” My mother listened, and I was angry at teacher and parent for many years because of it. I was also an artist, and won a San Diego school district wide art contest that same year I was teaching other first graders to read. The teacher gave me the blue ribbon to keep, but SHE kept MY painting! I lost blind trust in all teachers in first grade. Overall, probably not a bad thing. I’m not without college credits. I just don’t have any “lower division” (freshman or sophomore year) credits, therefore I have no degrees. But that’s a choice that I consciously made during my first year of college. After 2 weeks of freshman classes, I realized I was being “taught” things I’d already learned (with great redundancy!) in the 12 years of public school I had just completed. So I made an appointment with the president of the college and asked for his permission to take any classes I wanted that I thought would teach me something I wanted to know more about, whether it was nuclear physics or geology, William Shakespeare or Sigmund Freud. This was way back in 1953 at San Diego State College. Dr. Malcolm Love was its president then, but he is now deceased, though the main library of San Diego State University bears his name. Anyway, Dr. Love was quite amused by my request, warned me I would not get a degree without lower division credits, but after reading my transcripts he granted what I asked for with 1 condition: If any of the classes I signed up for carried a prerequisite, I had to meet with the instructor and get permission to take his class before enrolling. I followed that rule. And true to his word, Dr Love must have noted it in my records because it was still in force when I went back to school after my 18 year first marriage ended. It’s now 64 years later, I still have no degrees despite 2 matriculations at SDSU, but I have held numerous jobs in my lifetime that “required” a degree. I have taught in 2 universities and 3 post secondary schools. I’ve had a variety of careers and worked with and known some truly amazing people, including world renowned physicians, scientists, artists, musicians, and a spy (as in “espionage”) or two. My life experience has always been that if I have the knowledge base and skills required for a job, I will be accepted as a peer by those who have walls full of diplomas. But there is still one question that comes up on written applications and census forms that always stops me dead in my tracks! The question is: Education level? I don’t fit in society’s mold! But writing this has forced a little retrospection… As far as I can recall, the ONLY job applications I’ve ever filled out were for a summer job in a department store when I was in high school, and a job at the phone company when I was first married. I was “recruited” for all of my really interesting “professional” jobs. One of my greatest regrets is that the educational system of the United States is so inept at teaching kids how to think well, regardless of how bright or challenged the child may be. Mankind in general, but Americans specifically, seem incapable of distinguishing “can” from “should.” Which clearly states my dilemma over this Quora Question… I CAN answer this question, but should I?

This answer hinges on defining “uneducated” as not having had much education beyond basic public schooling. Many extremely intelligent people likely wouldn’t strike you as uneducated, so long as they had basic schooling at a young age. I personally have little in the way of formal education beyond 3 years of high school. I dropped out and got my GED after my junior year. In my mid 20’s, I took some college courses but eventually got bored with the extremely easy material and left college, eventually starting my own business and being fairly successful. Highly intelligent people are still just people, so they will vary from one to another, but I myself have always sort of absorbed information very quickly and easily. In college, while others scribbled notes to study later, I just listened to the lecture and remembered pretty much everything. I got pretty much all of the answers on the tests correct with the exception of answers that were gleaned from assigned reading material and absent from lectures, since I would rarely be that interested in the assigned reading material that was full of redundancies. They weren’t designed for people who quickly understand and absorb information. I got pretty much all A-’s without really cracking a book, until I got bored and stopped going. To be honest, I often find those who are highly educated but not particularly intelligent people to be some of the least tolerable people on the planet, because absent the intelligence to think on their own, they are so set in the ways of their “education” that they can’t conceive of the possibility that something they’ve been taught might not be scientifically, socially, or morally right. That’s why we’ve gone through periods where harmful procedures and practices have been the norm for a very, very long time without change, because educated people who don’t possess intelligence tend to rigidly stick to what they “learned”, rarely truly understanding why or how things work, only knowing that they do because someone else told them so. The 2 biggest indicators of intelligence are probably 2 simple questions: “How?” and “Why?”. Intelligent people seek to understand things. Almost everything makes sense when you dig enough. Knowing the answer isn’t enough. We need to know WHY it’s the answer, and HOW to arrive at that conclusion. Only through “how” and “why” can we have a deep enough understanding of any given topic to truly innovate in the field. You can’t make something work better if you don’t really know HOW that something works to begin with. In my opinion, the greatest minds among us don’t really need a formal education, particularly of the sort which can be obtained in most public universities in the US. An extremely intelligent individual who did a little bit of independent study in a field could probably convince a room full of experts from said field that he/she belongs among them, so long as credentials never have to be furnished, or references checked. I didn’t attend an elite, Ivy-league school, so I can’t comment on how the environment differs from public universities. But I surmise from my stint at a public university that such an intelligent person who obtains a degree probably does so more to show others they “know stuff about X” than to really “learn stuff about X”. We can learn on our own. We just need the educational certification to convince others that we know it, since most people don’t understand what it’s like for extremely intelligent individuals, and there are more liars than geniuses in this world. I routinely have friends who have medical issues and I guess their medical diagnosis, along with treatment, prior to them visiting the doctor. Amazingly often, their initial visit to the doctor results in a different diagnosis, which turns out to be wrong, and after 2–3 visits to different doctors, a specialist in a particular field ends up reaching the diagnosis that I took a stab at to begin with. I have no formal medical training(aside from psychology, which I suppose is loosely related), but I’ve heard people talk about their problems all my life, and I read a lot of non-fiction/news. So, without any formal medical training, people justifiably prefer to consult an “educated” doctor, but the truth is, intelligence and true understanding, even in intellectually elite fields like medicine, are almost as rare as it is in the general population. It’s just a bunch of people parroting things other people have told them, for the most part. And in this country, where kids are brought up being told they can be anything they want to be, so long as they work hard, it’s basically a cardinal sin to tell someone you were genetically gifted to be more intelligent than the average bear. Since there are many more liars than geniuses, a healthy majority won’t believe you, even if you furnish proof. And most that do believe you will view you with contempt, either due to some sort of subconscious jealousy, or due to some misguided personal theory that “IQ doesn’t matter”, which is really just a feel-good statement to make the majority of the population feel better about not being a genius. This all actually makes it suck to be a genius, by the way, so they really don’t need to feel bad about not being in this lonely black sheep club. Not only do people not understand you due to the communication range(as described here: The Inappropriately Excluded) , but they don’t even respect your intelligence. They often find highly intelligent people to be arrogant, aloof, or even stupid due to a lack of understanding. Much of this would presumably be resolved through a formal education, since it would grant said intelligent person a degree(pun intended) of authority. But, as in my case, by the time I’d had the life experiences to realize that people would never respect raw knowledge and intelligence if it isn’t certified by a piece of paper, it didn’t really make sense to spend years of monotonous schooling into my 30’s to “learn” things I already know, only to be in debt and incapable of making a better living than if I simply worked for all those years that I would have went to school and took control of my own future. I would have loved to have been a doctor, and I may even have contributed something important to the field, but in my experience, the system wasn’t designed for people like me. It was designed for people of above average intelligence to be able to become doctors, which inadvertently(I presume) alienates people like me, who can’t handle such a slow pace of education without getting bored. So I became a capitalist instead, which was absolutely designed for people like me. There is always room for innovation there, excellence is rewarded, and there is basically limitless potential for new experiences/knowledge. ;) Anyhow, since I mentioned it: If you don’t feel confident in your ability to discern a highly educated person’s true level of intelligence, I have only 1 recommendation when it comes to choosing a doctor, and it probably goes against conventional wisdom: Pick a young one. While less experienced, they will have been taught the most recent medical information, and won’t have so much anchoring bias working against recently discovered information that goes against whatever the status quo was at the time they became a doctor. There are some fantastic, intelligent, older doctors out there. But the vast majority of them are just going to be “average” doctors, subject to anchoring bias, and so I don’t recommend taking that gamble. Since they’re ALL educated in the specialized field of medicine, to the average person, ALL of them will likely sound “intelligent”, which is what makes them dangerous. Being educated and being intelligent are not one and the same. Being educated means knowing a solution someone else figured out. Being intelligent means being able to develop solutions to begin with. If you found this answer to sound arrogant or otherwise unpalatable, try starting over and reading it as if you were Data from Star Trek:TNG, or Ben Stein. Completely monotone with no inferred inflection. I’ve found that people tend to add emotional inflection and “tone” to my writing that doesn’t actually exist.
